30.1.1 Enabling and disabling Continental ENSC Sections depending on Power train Type
In case of hybrid projects (such as SCF) it?s requests to remove partially the Continental Engine Speed con-
troller, as the equivalent function is provided by the customer
For projects having a standard power train type based on a single combustion engine, the Continental Engine
Speed Controller must be enabled.
The following speci?c compiler switch allows to activate or disable some sections of the module "Engine speed
setpoint calculation (Appl. Inc.)" still need in hybrid systems
Value of the bit
Compiler switch bit number 0 1
NC_CONF_ENSL_ENA_403U 0 Calculation of Continental
"Basic engine speed" section
is disabled
Calculation of Continental
"Basic engine speed" section
is enabled
1 Calculation of Continental
"Basic engine speed at catalyst heating"
section
is disabled
Calculation of Continental
"Basic engine speed at catalyst heating"
section
is enabled

Ramping at interlock switch active (MT)
� General Information
The idle speed setpoint calculation needs to know the current state of the drive train (drive train open or
closed).
In case of manual transmission this information is obtained from the clutch sensor.
Depending on the project, different clutch information is used for determining the drive train state.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: At RST:
LV_N_SP_IS_CLU_OPEN = 0
Activation: LV_MT == 1
Deactivation: LV_MT == 0
Recurrence: 10MS

30.3.3 Overview of the driving off assistance
The function "Driving off assistance" shall prevent the engine from stalling at driving off. If the driving off
situation is detected (LV_DROF = 1) the idle speed controller will stay activated although PV >0. At the same
time the idle speed setpoint will be set to N_SP_IS_DROF. This engine speed setpoint depends on PV and
TCO.
Sequencing: This module shall be calculated before the module "Engine speed setpoint calculation" but after
the module "Detection of driver request passive".

30.3.3.1.6 Calculation of the engine speed setpoint for DROF
The setpoint for DROF depends on TCO and PV. It is also possible to raise the engine speed by driving off in
order to request more torque. For a smoothly drive off the engine speed setpoint is ?ltered with a ?lter factor
depending of engine speed error and pedal value gradient. The target here is to get a modelled setpoint which
raises slower than the actual engine speed but with a calibratable offset under it. The engine speed setpoint
by driving off is maximum selected with the global engine speed setpoint (N_SP_IS).

30.3.3.3 Determination of STATE_DROF
The variable STATE_DROF is created due to the different update rates in level 1 and level 2.
In the following circular buffer STATE_DROF, the last ?ve values of LV_DROF are stored:
This information is needed for the monitoring of the idle speed controller. It is updated every 10ms; the values
are shifted from Bit j to Bit j+1, j=0,1,2,3.

� General Information
Overview
Below the engine speed C_N_SP_IS_MAX_CLC, the engine speed set point calculation depends on the presents
of an automatic transmission, additional loads and the engine temperature.
The corrected idle speed set point N_SP_IS_COR is calculated, if some error conditions are present or the idle
speed set point needs to be increased, because the battery voltage is too low.
If an increase of the idle speed set point is requested by the EOL test, the idle speed set point is adjusted
according to the chosen case (VAG-test device mode 04).
The value N_SP_IS_CVT is calculated in Engine speed set point for transmission and N_SP_IS_EOL is calculated
in Engine speed set point for EOL .
Function structure

tems, in which part of the function they are and which variables are calculated in:

30.4.2.1 Compiler switch for selection of hybrid and non-hybrid based systems
Function for hybrid: Compiled
Example:
NC_PT_TYP_CMB_ENG= 0000 0001 
/*bit position for combustion engine vehicle variant is bit0*/
NC_PT_TYP_HYB= 0000 0010
/*bit position for hybrid vehicle variant is bit1*/
??????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????
NC_PT_TYP==0000 0001
/*This SW supports  vehicles with combustion only engine. 
Only combustion engine vehicle functions are compiled*/
NC_PT_TYP==0000 0010
/*This SW supports only Hybrid vehicles.
Only hybrid specific vehicle functions are compiled*/
NC_PT_TYP==0000 0011
/*This SW must support combustion only engine and hybrid vehicles. 
Both functionalities are compiled. 
LV_VAR_HYB decides which function must be used*/
Function for Non?hybrid: Compiled

30.4.2.3.1.2.5 Setting of the maximal current required idle speed (CLC_N_SP_IS_COR_MAX)
N_SP_IS_COR_MAX is determined as the maximum of N_SP_IS_BAS, N_SP_IS_RAMP and N_SP_IS_COR_DRIV. N_
SP_IS_COR_DRIV is determined thanks to N_SP_IS_COR (and so is in relation with the external required idle
speed). When the external request is over, it is kept in memory instead of a lower idle speed, until a driver
engine speed increase: then, this lower idle speed is recovered.

30.4.2.3.1.2.6 Calculation of the difference between basic and external required idle speed (CLC_N_SP_
DIF)
N_SP_DIF is the difference between the corrected idle speed set point and the basic idle speed set point. This
difference is calculated as well, if an idle speed set point higher than the corrected idle speed set point is used,
because of the maximum selection. In this case N_SP_DIF is limited to zero.

30.4.2.3.1.3.1 Idle speed setpoint in sport plus mode
If driver selects the SPORT PLUS program, the idle speed setpoint is increased to a speci?c value. This increase
of engine speed at idle improves the transition from idle speed to partial load giving a faster response to driver
request.

This increase
of engine speed at idle improves the transition from idle speed to partial load giving a faster response to driver
request.
An additional setpoint is available in case of driver selects the SPORT program
Cal Hint:
- CLF_N_SP_IS_DRIV_MOD_AT and CLF_N_SP_IS_DRIV_MOD_MT activates the possibility to increase the idle
speed setpoint in case of driver selects for example SPORT or SPORT PLUS
- CLF_N_SP_IS_DRIV_MOD_SPT_AT and CLF_N_SP_IS_DRIV_MOD_SPT_MT decide which set point must be used: the
speci?c for SPORT or the one for SPORT PLUS.

30.4.2.3.2.2 Corrected idle speed set point calculation (CLC_N_SP_IS_CLC)
When speed is falling with high negative gradients at the actual engine speed N with N_DIF <0 (over speed),
an interception function should be active to prevent transient effects round the idle speed set point N_SP_IS.
These transient effects are normally caused by high integral part values, which may result from activating
the idle speed controller at high speed deviations. In order to prevent such situations, a corrected set point
N_SP_IS_CLC is calculated, which is catching engine speed to idle speed. This value leads to smaller deviations
to the (corrected) set point with slighter controller outputs. With the calibration of the ?lter parameters IP_
CRLC_N_SP_IS_CLC (depending on gearbox type) it can be ensured that ?ltering is only active at over speed
(N_DIF<0).

30.4.2.3.2.2.4 Initial ?ltering (N_SP_IS_CLC_LPF)
In this block the ?lter function of N_SP_IS_CLC_LPF is executed.
The PT1 ?lter is at reset state in case of LV_N_SP_IS_CLC_LPF_RST = true. If the reset variable becomes false the
?ltering to the target value is active.
The target value is selectable via C_CON_N_SP_IS_CLC:
C_CONF_N_SP_IS_CLC bit0 = 0: the target value for the ?lter algorithm is N_SP_IS_CLC_LPF_INI_1
C_CONF_N_SP_IS_CLC bit0 = 1: the target value for the ?lter algorithm is N_SP_IS_CLC_LIM_TAR
C_CONF_N_SP_IS_CLC bit1 = 1: the target value is switched depending on LV_DT (in case of open drivetrain N_
SP_IS_CLC_LIM_TAR is the target value, at closed drivetrain N_SP_IS_CLC_LPF_INI_1 is the target for the ?lter).
The bit1 of C_CONF_N_SP_IS_CLC bit1 is prior to bit0.

In order to avoid later instability in TQ_MIN_CLU, the engine speed input for the calculation of N_SP_IS_RATIO
may be ?ltered. Two ?lter constants are available (idle and not idle), these may be calibrated so that for small
?lter differences, the ?ltering is slow and for large ?lter differences the ?ltering is faster.

quotient between the actual engine speed and the corrected engine speed setpoint at idle. The secound way
offers a calculation based on the actual engine speed and the static engine speed setpoint at idle.

30.4.2.3.3.3 Final speed relation N_SP_IS_RATIO (SET_N_SP_IS_RATIO)
In case of selected variant with delay time after start the speed relation N_SP_IS_RATIO keeps the initialization
value until the transition to normal calculation is triggered. The conditions for a transition are the following:
* Normal transition (N_SP_IS_RATIO_BAS within a adjustable time in a transfer range close to 1,000)
* Fast transition in case of engine start with LV_CT = 0
* Transition via ramp function in case of LV_CT = 1 during after start and no normal mode
* Forced transition after a adjustable time in case of no triggered transfer conditions

ENSC, Engine speed setpoint calculation (Appl. Inc.)
� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
In this module the basic engine speed setpoint for idle is calculated. Based on the basic maps (dependancy
TCO and TOIL) there is the possibility to correct this value by several additional subfunction (e.g failure in IVVT
system).
This module has to be executed before "N_SP_IS calculation" (coordination of N_SP_IS requests).
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, IGKOFF, IGKON
Activation: N<C_N_SP_IS_MAX_CLC
Deactivation: N>=C_N_SP_IS_MAX_CLC
Recurrence: 10MS

� General Information
The main interest of building up a torque reserve in idle is to de?ne an operating point for the ignition angle
to be able to increase torque very fast in case of critical situations and to get steady state conditions. The
amount of torque reserve is calibratable it depends on the requested compromise between idle stability and
fuel consumption.

Figure 30.6.2:
30.6.1 Idle Speed Torque Reserve
The module "Idle speed torque reserve consists of two parts:
1. Idle speed torque reserve due to low engine speed. This torque reserve is determined in dependance
of a predicted speed deviation N_DIF_PRED to prepare fast ignition angle reactions for torque increasing re-
quests.
2. Idle speed torque reserve limitiation for stabilizing idle speed at high torque reserves. This torque reserve
is an offset to the maximum allowed torque reserve; it enables ignition reaction to reduce torque, which is
not possible without an offset to the minimum ignition angle. This stabilizes idle speed at high torque reserve
requests (f.e. catalyst heating).

30.6.1.1 Determination of the Torque reserve
Depending on the predicted engine speed difference N_DIF_PRED a torque reserve by increasing the load
is calculated. If actual engine speed falls it is possible to increase load before the actual engine speed is
below the engine speed setpoint for idle speed. At the same time a spark retard compensates the supposed
torque increase. So a quick torque incraease by spark advance can be realized to stabilize engine speed at its
setpoint.
For negative gradients of TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_1 a PT1-?lter for TQ_ADD_IS_BOL calculation is applied to avoid torque
jumps caused by fast changes of ignition angle. For positive gradients of the input TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_1 the output
value TQ_ADD_IS_BOL is identical to the input.
After engine start N_DIF_PRED is set to zero as long as a positive ?ltered engine speed gradient is detected
and the calculated N_DIF_PRED_1 is negative. During this period the torque reserve stays constant.
For driving off, a special torque reserve offset can be added.

ENSC, Idle speed torque reserve
30.6.1.2 Determination of Offset to Max
At high torque reserve requests (ex.: catalyst heating) the ignition angle can be retarded down to the minimum
ignition angle IGA_MIN. This may cause problems with idle speed stability. In order to prevent speed from
oscillating in case the actual ignition angle is in the near of IGA_MIN caused by high torque reserves, the
maximum availible torque reserve must be limited. In order to reach this, a tunable calibration constant C_TQ_
ADD_MAX_OFS_IS is introduced. C_TQ_ADD_MAX_OFS_IS has the same in?uence than TQ_ADD_IS_BOL: while
the last de?nes a minimum torque reserve, C_TQ_ADD_MAX_OFS_IS takes in?uence on the maximum torque
reserve in idle.
Figure 30.6.10:
Available torque reserve range after limiting: TQI_ADD_MAX_TOL - C_TQ_ADD_MAX_OFS_IS de?nes the maxi-
mum torque reserve in idle
Since C_TQ_ADD_MAX_OFS_IS is a calibratable constant, this may cause a con?ict:
Figure 30.6.11:
Limiting C_TQ_ADD_MAX_OFS_IS in case of a con?ict
In this case TQ_ADD_IS_BOL has a higher priority than C_TQ_ADD_MAX_OFS_IS, since the possibility of moving
the ignition angle in direction spark advance by building up a torque reserve is more essential than keeping it

is
DRIVER_REQUEST + TQ_ADD_IS_BOL <= TQI_ADD_MAX_TOL -
C_TQ_ADD_MAX_OFS_IS. (1)
Solving this relation leads to
C_TQ_ADD_MAX_OFS_IS <= TQI_ADD_MAX_TOL - DRIVER_REQUEST -
TQ_ADD_IS_BOL. (2)

ENSC, Idle speed torque reserve (Appl. Inc.)
� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
In Idle speed torque reserve (Appl. Inc.) customer speci?c idle speed torque reserve requests can be de?ned.
The following interfaces are available:
- TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_CUS, which is an absolute torque reserve request, the activation is depending on LV_TQ_
ADD_IS_BOL_CUS.
- TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_CUS_MIN de?nes a minimum torque reserve in idle.
- TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_OFS is an offset torque reserve to TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_1 in Idle speed torque reserve.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, IGKON, IGKOFF, ERU2ES, Deactivation
Activation: LV_IGK&&LV_REQ_ISC
Deactivation: if activation not true
Recurrence: 10MS
� Function Description

30.7.3.3 Calculation of TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_OFS
In this subfunction the offset TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_OFS is calculated.
There is a con?guration byte included with the following meaning:
- C_CONF_TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_OFS bit0: enable of TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_DROF_OFS_CLU in case clutch switch
- C_CONF_TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_OFS bit1: enable of TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_DROF_OFS_CLU in case brake switch
- C_CONF_TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_OFS bit2: enable TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_DROF_OFS_CLU calculation in case of active DROF
function
- C_CONF_TQ_ADD_IS_BOL_OFS bit3: selection of calculation method (PV_CLU or LV_CLU_SWI)
30.7.3.3.1 Calculation of additional torque reserve in case of DROF
In case of active torque reserve for driving off calculation the method of calculation (based on actual clutch
value or clutch switch) can be selected.

� General Information
If the difference to the nominal idle speed keeps too high or too low in spite of an activated idle speed con-
troller, an idle speed control plausibility error is detected. The error detection algorithm is active under certain
conditions such as stopped vehicle, VS=0, reaching of a delay time since LV_ST_END =0->1 or end of after start
reached. Due to different engine operating characteristics the cold start diagnosis is performed by using limits
depending on the temperature of cooling water and time after start.
The bit coded variables with the following meaning are interface to error management (ERRM):
Bit 0: Condition ful?lled if set to 1
Bit 1: Failure symptom present if set to 1
Bit 2: Failure not yet de-bounced if set to 1; only used if ?lter service from ERRM not used.
Examples:
LF_STATE_DGO_N_ORNG_H_ISC set to ...
0: no diagnostic condition
1: condition and no symptom, diagnostic passed.
3: condition and symptom present; diagnostic failed
5: condition and no symptom, not yet de-bounced
7: condition and symptom present, not yet de-bounced
For detailed information regarding the error detection mechanism see anti bounce algorithm, respectively the
generic error management.

30.8.2.1.3 Idle speed control diagnose inhibition in case of dynamic idle speed setpoint
While the idle speed setpoint increases or decreases, a deviation between current engine speed and idle
speed setpoint is possible. This deviation must not be considered as an erroneous state.
Therefore during these dynamic states, the diagnosis must be inhibited until a steady setpoint is reached
and
the idle speed controller had enough time to stabilize the system.
The inhibition must be only calculated while engine is running and idle speed state is active.
If C_N_INT_DEC_SP_IS_DIAG_INH is set o 0 rpm, the inhibition is disabled always.

30.8.2.1.3.1 Check of dynamic conditions for Idle speed control diagnose inhibition
While the idle speed setpoint increases or decreases, a deviation between current engine speed and idle
speed setpoint is possible. This deviation must not be considered as an erroneous state.
Therefore during these dynamic states, the diagnosis must be inhibited until a steady setpoint is reached
and
the idle speed controller had enough time to stabilize the system.
The change of the idle speed setpoint is integrated without considering the sign of the change. At every
recurrence, the integral is reduced by a constant, This constant represents the reduction of the integral per
recurrence - ->the time that the diagnosis inhibition stays after idle speed setpoint is constant
The change of idle speed setpoint must be higher than a minimum value for being considered in the integral.
Smaller engine speed setpoint changes must not lead to inhibition of the diagnosis -idle speed controller
and system are fast enough to compensate it.
When the Integral value is higher than a threshold, the diagnosis is inhibited. And once the integral is
reduced to 0, the diagnosis inhibition is released again.
The integral is limited by a value so the maximum allowed duration of the inhibition, after idle speed setpoint
is constant, can be guaranteed.
Calibration hints:
- This feature can be disabled by setting C_N_INT_DEC_SP_IS_DIAG_INH == 0
- Maximum time for removing the inhibition after N_SP_IS is constant:
100ms * (C_N_INT_MAX_SP_IS_DIAG_INH / C_N_INT_DEC_SP_IS_DIAG_INH)

30.8.2.1.4 Inhibition of idle speed diagnosis at high engine loads
In case of the engine is producing a high engine torque output, the diagnosis of idle speed controller is in-
hibited. The high engine load is caused by external parameters such as a slipping clutch for uphill driving off,
high torque consumption of external aggregates or other ambient limiting factors. All them may lead to an
engine speed below the setpoint requested by idle speed controller. The high engine load shows that engine
is responding to idle speed request.
An additional calibration C_TQI_IS_MAX_DIAG_ISC allows to add the speci?c torque limits that may applied to
the idle speed controller output. In case of idle speed controller is not limited to any particular value, please
set the value C_TQI_IS_MAX_DIAG_ISC to maximum.
This inhibition is only valid if the engine speed is below the idle set point: The diagnosis cannot be activated
if low idle speed is detected but the engine is already producing a high torque output. Under those condition
the reason for the low idle are not a related with a bad function in idle speed controller.

30.8.2.2 ENSC_MA09C/OPM_ISC_DIAG/ISC_CST_DIAG
If the engine speed deviation persists by an activated controller, the error is only set after the integral part of
the controller has reached one of its limits. In case of persistent overspeed, the integral part is checked against
its bottom limit (N>N_SP_IS) and against its top limit in case of persitent underspeed (N<N_SP_IS).

30.8.2.2.2.1 Calculation of timer T_DLY_TQ_DIF_I_IS_DIAG_CST.
In general the delay timer shall be deactivated by setting C_T_DLY_TQ_DIF_I_IS_DIAG_CST / C_T_DLY_TQ_DIF_IS_
DIAG_CST to 0 in order to avoid an asymmetrical diagnosis behavior for pass and fail situations. It only may
be used in case that ABC entries in the shadow error memory are forbidden - but then the delay time shall not
be longer than 10 percent of the ABC time.

30.8.2.3 ERRM ResultDiag call for CST
30.8.2.4 ENSC_MA09C/OPM_ISC_DIAG/ISC_DIAG
If the engine speed deviation persists by an activated controller, the error is only set after the integral part of
the controller has reached one of its limits. In case of persistent overspeed, the integral part is checked against
its bottom limit (N>N_SP_IS) and against its top limit in case of persitent underspeed (N<N_SP_IS).

30.8.2.4.1.1 When RPM too high
In general the delay timer shall be deactivated by setting C_T_DLY_TQ_DIF_I_IS_DIAG/
C_T_DLY_TQ_DIF_IS_DIAG to 0 in order to avoid an asymmetrical diagnosis behavior for pass and fail situations.
It only may be used in case that ABC entries in the shadow error memory are forbidden - but then the delay
time shall not be longer than 10 percent of the ABC time.

ACTION_ENSC_IniRbmClcIscCstH(IN <PRM_TYP_INI>, IN <PRM_NR_CONF>) Mode: O
This action is called by ERRM aggregate to force a new evaluation of rate-based monitoring data of diagnosis
(STATE_RBM_ISC_CST_H = 0) or to remove rate-based monitoring inhibition related to system fault ( bit 1 of STATE_RBM_ISC_CST_H =
0)

30.9.1 Cold start idle speed counter
� General Information
For the special CSERS denomination of the idle speed control diagnosis under cold start conditions the accu-
mulated time in state "catalyst heating" in keeping with "cold start idle speed set point active" is calculated here.
The timer is only reset with the start of a new driving cycle.
� Application Conditions
Activation: LV_IGK = 1
Recurrence: 100 ms

30.9.2 Interface for Rate-Based-Monitoring
� General Information
With this module the interface between the ISC_CST monitor and the Rate-Based Monitoring statistics is de-
?ned with STAE_RBM_ISC_H / -L date.
Within STATE_RBM_ISC_CST_x, three different information are de?ned:
- Conditions for monitoring are met long enough to detect malfunction (bit 0)
(no intrusive operation, no short trip)

� Calibration Flowchart:

� Calibration Process:
� Idle speed torque reserve
The aim of the calibration is to increase torque reserve for a predicted decreasing engine speed. Besides, an
offset for the maximum allowed torque reserve in idle can be de?ned to prevent engine speed oscillations at
very high torque reserve requests.
Calibration label Calibration advice
C_TQ_DIF_ADD_IS_TOL Start with 2Nm. Take any map to de?ne a torque reserve request and put in such high
values that minimum ignition angle is reached. If engine speed is oscillating, increase
C_TQ_DIF_ADD_IS_TOL as long until oscillation stops. If speed is not osillating, reduce
C_TQ_DIF_ADD_IS_TOL as long as speed starts ocillation and increase again until engine
speed is stable again. Keep the value as small as possible to get the largest torque reserve
range with stable engine speed conditions.
IP_T_N_DIF_OFS_PRED Put in the speed dependant time constant for air path dynamics.
IP_TQ_ADD_IS_BOL The values should increase for increasing predicted underspeed. The slope must be
chosen such a way that speed stays stable. Calibration:

engine speed stays stable.

N_DIF_PRED. The value for this limitation
can be determined as follows: every
engine has a typical engine speed
roughness, which is expressed in the engine
speed gradient movements.Calculate the
maximum reachable
N_DIF_PRED for these gradients. The value
you get here is a limit from which
TQ_ADD_IS_BOL can be increased steeper
(stronger predicted underspeed). For smaller
N_DIF_PRED the characeristic of
the curve should be ?at to prevent engine
speed excitement. Mind not to

This image represents a Simulink (or similar block-diagram modeling tool like TargetLink) diagram for an automotive control system.

## Function

The primary function of this system, named "ENSC. Driving off assistance," is to provide assistance during vehicle "driving off" (starting from a standstill or very low speed maneuvers). It processes various vehicle and driver inputs to determine the state of the driving-off assistance, calculate target torque values, and generate control signals for the powertrain (likely engine and/or transmission torque control). The system executes cyclically every 10 milliseconds and initializes upon system reset and ignition on.

## Inputs

The system receives a wide array of inputs, which can be categorized as follows:

**System Control & Configuration:**
*   `<fc_RST>`: System reset signal.
*   `<fc_IGKON>`: Ignition On signal.
*   `fc_INI`: Initialization function call/flag (from scheduler).
*   `fc_OPM_10MS`: Operation mode/scheduling flag for 10ms recurrence (from scheduler).
*   `<NLC_CONF_ENSC_ENA_4067>`: Configuration parameter for enabling/disabling the ENSC function.
*   `<ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3>`: Permission or status from an "ACTION_FARM" component.

**Vehicle Status & Sensors:**
*   `<LV_AT>`: Automatic Transmission status.
*   `<LV_CVT>`: Continuously Variable Transmission status.
*   `<N_B2>`: Engine speed or similar rotational speed.
*   `<GEAR>`: Current gear selection.
*   `<GEAR_SENS>`: Gear sensor reading.
*   `<N>`: Rotational speed (e.g., engine or wheel speed).
*   `<VS_H_RES>`: Vehicle speed high resolution.
*   `<N_SP_IS>`: Slip speed (possibly between wheel and ground or engine/transmission).

**Driver Inputs & Requests:**
*   `<PV>`: Pedal value (e.g., accelerator pedal position).
*   `<LV_BTS>`: Brake pedal switch status.
*   `<TCO>`: Throttle control input (e.g., from cruise control or driver).
*   `<LV_CLU_SWI>`: Clutch switch status.
*   `<PV_CLU>`: Clutch pedal value.
*   `<PV_CLU_GRD>`: Clutch pedal gradient (rate of change).
*   `<LV_DROF_CUS>`: Customer-specific driving-off assistance level or request.
*   `<N_SP_IS_DROF_CUS>`: Customer-specific slip speed target for driving off.
*   `<N_DIF_DROF_CUS>`: Customer-specific differential speed target for driving off.

**System/Mode Flags:**
*   `<LV_ASR_ACT>`: Anti-Slip Regulation (ASR) active status.
*   `<LV_MSR_ACT>`: Motor Slip Regulation (MSR) active status.
*   `<PV_AV_GRD>`: Average gradient (road incline/decline).
*   `<LV_ES>`: Engine Start/Stop system status.
*   `<NO_NR_GEAR_NEU>`: Status regarding Neutral gear.
*   `feedback`: Generic feedback signal (origin not explicitly shown but implies internal or external feedback).

## Outputs

The system produces several outputs related to its control and status:

**Driving Off Assistance Status:**
*   `<LV_DROF>`: Level Driving Off (main status of the assistance function).
*   `<LV_DROF_INH>`: Driving Off Inhibit status (indicates if the function is inhibited).
*   `<STATE_DROF>`: Current state of the driving-off assistance function (e.g., active, inactive, waiting).

**Torque Control & Reference Values:**
*   `<N_DIF_DROF>`: Differential speed reference for driving off.
*   `<N_SP_IS_DROF>`: Slip speed reference for driving off.
*   `<LV_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT>`: Level Torque Percentage Control Driving Off Motor/Transmission (e.g., percentage of available torque).
*   `<TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT>`: Torque Percentage Control Driving Off Motor/Transmission (absolute or commanded torque value).

## Logic Flow

The logical flow of the system can be described in these steps:

1.  **Task Scheduling and Initialization (Top-Left Orange Block):**
    *   The system is configured to execute periodically every **10 milliseconds** (`Recurrence: 10MS`).
    *   **Initialization (`Init: RST IGKON`)** occurs when a `RST` (Reset) signal and an `IGKON` (Ignition On) signal are active.

**Task Scheduling and Initialization (Top-Left Orange Block):**
    *   The system is configured to execute periodically every **10 milliseconds** (`Recurrence: 10MS`).
    *   **Initialization (`Init: RST IGKON`)** occurs when a `RST` (Reset) signal and an `IGKON` (Ignition On) signal are active. This sets up the initial conditions for the system.
    *   The system is designed to be **always active (`Activation: always`)** once initialized, meaning it continuously processes inputs and generates outputs according to its 10ms cycle.
    *   It has no explicit deactivation condition (`Deactivation: never`).
    *   This block generates signals like `fc_INI` (initialization function call) and `fc_OPM_10MS` (operation mode for the 10ms cycle), which likely trigger the execution of other sub-components.

2.  **System Readiness & Ignition Logic (INI_IGKON X.2 Block):**
    *   This sub-system receives external reset (`<fc_RST>`) and ignition (`<fc_IGKON>`) signals, as well as the internal `fc_INI` from the scheduler.
    *   It also contains an internal `RST` block (X.1), suggesting local reset logic.
    *   Its primary role is to determine the overall system readiness based on reset and ignition status, outputting `ini_igkon` (likely "initialized and ignition on") and an `opm` (operating mode) signal. This ensures the core driving-off assistance logic only operates when the vehicle's electrical system and the software are properly started.

3.  **Core Driving Off Assistance Logic (DROF X.3 Block):**
    *   This is the central computational block where the main driving-off assistance algorithms reside.
    *   It takes the `ini_igkon` and `opm` signals as enablers or mode selectors.
    *   A multitude of vehicle state (e.g., gear, speeds, transmission type), driver input (e.g., pedals, clutch), and system status (e.g., ASR/MSR active, configurations) inputs are fed into this block.
    *   Inside the `DROF X.3` block, these inputs are processed according to predefined algorithms, which likely involve:
        *   **State Machine Logic:** To transition between different operational states (e.g., idle, active, error, inhibited) for the driving-off assistance function.
        *   **Condition Evaluation:** Checking safety conditions, driver requests, and vehicle thresholds to determine when assistance is needed, allowed, or should be inhibited.
        *   **Control Algorithm:** Calculating the required target torque (`TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT`) and its corresponding level (`LV_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT`), as well as other reference values (`N_DIF_DROF`, `N_SP_IS_DROF`) to achieve smooth and controlled vehicle starts.
        *   **Feedback Integration:** The `feedback` line suggests that outputs or internal states of this block might be fed back, potentially for closed-loop control, state memory, or interaction with other sub-systems.
    *   The outputs of this block reflect the computed state of the assistance function and the calculated torque commands.

4.  **Output Generation:** The calculated outputs are then propagated to other vehicle control units (e.g., Engine Control Unit, Transmission Control Unit) to implement the actual torque adjustments and influence vehicle behavior during driving off.

This image contains Simulink-style diagrams illustrating initialization procedures for an automotive control system.

## Function

The primary function of these diagrams is to describe the initialization of the "Driving off assistance" system, which aims to prevent engine stalling during the process of a vehicle driving away from a standstill. Two distinct initialization scenarios are presented:

## Function

This Simulink diagram defines the logic for the **Low Voltage Driving Off Inhibition (LV_DROF_INH)** signal, which is part of an "ENSC. Driving off assistance" system. Its primary function is to determine when the Driving Off assistance system (DROF) should be inhibited based on a combination of vehicle status, permission checks, and a project-specific configuration switch.

## Inputs

1.  **LV_ES**: A boolean signal, likely indicating a low voltage state or an engine start/stop condition.
2.  **cond_if**: A boolean input, its source is not fully shown but it receives `NOT LV_ES`. This acts as a conditional input to the overall logic.
3.  **ACTION_FARM_GetPermission**: A boolean signal indicating permission status from a "FARM" action (e.g., a function responsible for managing certain system activations or permissions).
4.  **NO_FID_ERR_ISC_DROF_INH**: A boolean signal, likely indicating the absence of a fault (No Fault IDentified Error) related to the ISC (Idle Speed Control?) or DROF inhibition.
5.  **LC_INH_DROF_PRJ**: A boolean or integer signal representing a "Logical switch to use the project specific inhibition condition".
6.  **PRM_FID_ACTION_FARM_GetPermission**: This appears to be a parameter or configuration input to the `ActionImport` block, influencing how the permissions are evaluated.

## Outputs

1.  **LV_DROF_INH**: A boolean signal (final output) which is TRUE when the Driving Off assistance system is inhibited, and FALSE otherwise.

6.  **PRM_FID_ACTION_FARM_GetPermission**: This appears to be a parameter or configuration input to the `ActionImport` block, influencing how the permissions are evaluated.

## Outputs

1.  **LV_DROF_INH**: A boolean signal (final output) which is TRUE when the Driving Off assistance system is inhibited, and FALSE otherwise.

## Logic Flow

The diagram calculates the `LV_DROF_INH` output by combining three main logical paths using an `AND` gate (V.6.6). For `LV_DROF_INH` to be TRUE (meaning DROF is inhibited), all three conditions must be met:

1.  **Low Voltage / Engine State Condition (Path 1):**
    *   The input signal `LV_ES` is first processed by a `NOT` gate (V.6.3).
    *   The inverted signal (`NOT LV_ES`) is then fed into a `cond_if` block (V.6.0). The exact internal logic of `cond_if` is not fully visible, but its output is one of the conditions for `LV_DROF_INH`. This implies that `cond_if` must evaluate to TRUE.

2.  **Permission and Error Condition (Path 2):**
    *   `ACTION_FARM_GetPermission`, `NO_FID_ERR_ISC_DROF_INH`, and `PRM_FID_ACTION_FARM_GetPermission` are all fed into an `ActionImport` block (V.6.11). This block likely consolidates or evaluates these inputs to produce a combined permission status.
    *   The output of the `ActionImport` block is `PRM_LV_PRMS`. This signal probably indicates the status of permissions related to low voltage parameters.
    *   `PRM_LV_PRMS` is then passed through a `NOT` gate (V.6.2).
    *   The output (`NOT PRM_LV_PRMS`) becomes the second input to the final `AND` gate. This means that for inhibition to occur, `PRM_LV_PRMS` must be FALSE (i.e., permissions are *not* granted, or there's an error condition that `NO_FID_ERR_ISC_DROF_INH` might override).

3.  **Project-Specific Inhibition Switch (Path 3):**
    *   The input signal `LC_INH_DROF_PRJ` is compared to a constant value `1` using an equality block (V.6.2). The constant `1` is labeled "inhibition active".
    *   This comparison effectively checks if the project-specific inhibition switch is active (`LC_INH_DROF_PRJ == 1`).
    *   The boolean result of this comparison is the third input to the final `AND` gate.

**Final Output Calculation:**
All three boolean outputs (from `cond_if`, `NOT PRM_LV_PRMS`, and `(LC_INH_DROF_PRJ == 1)`) are fed into an `AND` gate (V.6.6). The `LV_DROF_INH` signal becomes TRUE only if **ALL three** of these intermediate conditions are TRUE. If any of these conditions are FALSE, `LV_DROF_INH` will be FALSE, meaning the DROF assistance system is not inhibited.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate and control the **Torque Precontrol during Drive Off with a Manual Gearbox (`TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT`)**. ## Inputs

1.  **`FAC_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT`**: A scaling factor applied to the base raw torque.
2.  **`IP_CLU_GRD`**: An input representing the clutch gradient or engagement state, used as an independent variable for lookup tables.
3.  **`LV_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT`**: A lower limit value used to constrain the raw precontrol torque.

## Inputs

1.  **`FAC_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT`**: A scaling factor applied to the base raw torque.
2.  **`IP_CLU_GRD`**: An input representing the clutch gradient or engagement state, used as an independent variable for lookup tables.
3.  **`LV_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT`**: A lower limit value used to constrain the raw precontrol torque.

*(Note: `x_val`, `y_val` for lookup tables and `m`, `R`, `IV` for saturation/rate limiters are considered calibration parameters rather than dynamic inputs for the overall system.)*

## Outputs

1.  **`TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_RAW>`**: The raw, un-filtered, and un-rate-limited precontrol torque, potentially after a lower limit check.
2.  **`TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT>`**: The final, calculated and controlled precontrol torque for drive-off.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow of the diagram can be divided into two main parallel paths – a **Raw Torque Path** and a **Smoothed Torque Path** – whose outputs are then combined by a final selection logic.

**1. Raw Torque Path:**

*   **Base Torque Lookup (Upper Lookup Table, V.7.11):** The `IP_CLU_GRD` signal is fed into a 1-D lookup table (defined by `x_val` and `y_val`) to generate a base torque value, `IP_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT`. This block likely maps the clutch state to a desired initial torque.
*   **Scaling (Gain Block, V.7.8):** The `IP_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT` is multiplied by the `FAC_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT` factor. The output of this multiplication is the `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_RAW>` signal.
*   **Lower Limit Application (Switch V.6.10):** The `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_RAW>` signal is compared with `LV_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT`.
    *   If `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_RAW>` is greater than or equal to `LV_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT` (condition `Check >= 0` is true), the `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_RAW>` value is passed through.
    *   If `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_RAW>` is less than `LV_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT`, a constant `0` (from V.6.11) is selected. This effectively ensures the raw torque does not go below zero (or a specific lower threshold defined by `LV_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT` if it was positive). The output of this switch is an intermediate raw, limited torque value, further labeled `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old` as it feeds into the final selection logic.

**2. Smoothed Torque Path:**

*   **Reference Torque Lookup (Lower Lookup Table, V.7.11):** `IP_CLU_GRD` is again fed into another 1-D lookup table to generate `IP_CRLC_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT`. This likely represents a target torque value that needs to be achieved smoothly.
*   **First Rate Limiter/Saturation (Block V.7.7):** `IP_CRLC_TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT` enters a block that combines rate limiting and saturation. This block uses parameters `m`, `u`, `R`, `IV`, and has internal state variables `x_in`, `x_out` with a unit delay `1/z` (represented by `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old2`). Its purpose is to smoothly ramp the torque demand and keep it within defined limits. The output is `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old2`.
*   **Second Rate Limiter/Saturation (Block V.7.7):** The output `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old2` is fed into an identical second rate limiter/saturation block. This further smooths and rate-limits the signal, producing `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old3`. Chaining these blocks enhances the smoothing effect.

The output is `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old2`.
*   **Second Rate Limiter/Saturation (Block V.7.7):** The output `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old2` is fed into an identical second rate limiter/saturation block. This further smooths and rate-limits the signal, producing `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old3`. Chaining these blocks enhances the smoothing effect.
*   **Track-if-Lower / Decreasing Rate Limiter (Blocks V.6.6 and V.6.8):** The `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old3` signal is compared with its previous delayed value `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old1` (which is the output of the switch V.6.8 after a unit delay `1/z`).
    *   The `less than` comparator (V.6.6) checks if `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old3 < TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old1`.
    *   The saturation-like switch (V.6.8) selects: if `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old3` is indeed less than `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old1`, then `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old3` is chosen. Otherwise, `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old1` (the previous value) is maintained. This creates a behavior where the output tracks `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old3` if it decreases, but holds its value if `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old3` attempts to increase beyond the current `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old1`. This effectively acts as a rate limiter for decreasing values or a minimum tracker. The output of this block, after the `1/z` delay, becomes `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old1`.

**3. Final Torque Selection:**

*   **Comparison (V.6.10):** The intermediate raw, limited torque from the upper path (`TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old`) is compared with the smoothed, rate-limited torque from the lower path (`TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old1`). A "greater than or equal to" comparator checks `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old >= TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old1`.
*   **Final Switch (V.6.10):** A final switch block selects the ultimate precontrol torque `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT>` based on this comparison:
    *   If `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old >= TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old1` (raw torque is higher or equal to smoothed torque), the system selects `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old` (the raw, limited torque). This ensures a prompt response to increasing torque demands.
    *   If `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old < TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old1` (raw torque is lower than smoothed torque), the system selects `TQ_PCTL_DROF_MT_old1` (the smoothed, rate-limited torque). This prioritizes the smooth reduction or tracking of a lower demand, preventing jerky responses.

In summary, the system generates a torque precontrol signal that is quickly responsive to increases in demand (driven by the raw calculation) but smoothly controlled and rate-limited during decreases or when a smooth target is preferable. This is a robust strategy for controlling engine torque during drive-off with a manual gearbox.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to create a 5-bit historical state variable, `STATE_DROF`, by concatenating the current and past four samples of a discrete input signal, `DLV_DROF`, into a single integer output. It essentially functions as a 5-bit shift register, where each bit of the output represents the `DLV_DROF` signal at a different point in time. This pattern is commonly used in automotive systems for sequence detection, debouncing, or maintaining short-term memory of a signal's behavior.

## Inputs

*   **DLV_DROF (Boolean/Discrete):** This is the main input signal. Given the context "Driving off assistance," it likely represents a binary state or event related to the vehicle driving off (e.g., active/inactive, true/false for a driving-off condition).

## Outputs

*   **STATE_DROF (Integer):** This is the single output of the subsystem. It's an integer value where each of its first five least significant bits (bit 0 to bit 4) corresponds to a specific historical state of the `DLV_DROF` input.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow can be described step-by-step as follows:

1.  **Initialization:**
    *   The process begins with an initial `num_dec` value of `0`.
    *   All `1/z` (unit delay) blocks are initialized to `0`. This means that at the very first sample time, their outputs will be `0`.

2.  **Current `DLV_DROF` (Bit 0):**
    *   The first `WRITE BIT` block (with `bit_sel = 0`) takes the initial `num_dec` value of `0`.
    *   It takes the *current* instantaneous value of the `DLV_DROF` input signal as its `bit` input.
    *   It writes this `DLV_DROF` value into bit position 0 of the `num_dec` value. The output `y` (let's call it `y_0`) now contains the current `DLV_DROF` state in its least significant bit.

3.  **`DLV_DROF` from 1 Sample Ago (Bit 1):**
    *   The current `DLV_DROF` input also feeds into the first `1/z` unit delay block (initialized to `0`).
    *   The output of this `1/z` block is `DLV_DROF` from the *previous* sample time (let's call it `DLV_DROF_delayed_1`).
    *   A second `WRITE BIT` block (with `bit_sel = 1`) takes `y_0` (the result from the previous `WRITE BIT` operation) as its `num_dec` input.
    *   It takes `DLV_DROF_delayed_1` as its `bit` input.
    *   It writes `DLV_DROF_delayed_1` into bit position 1 of `y_0`. The output `y` (now `y_1`) contains the current `DLV_DROF` in bit 0 and `DLV_DROF` from 1 sample ago in bit 1.

4.  **`DLV_DROF` from 2 Samples Ago (Bit 2):**
    *   `DLV_DROF_delayed_1` feeds into a second `1/z` unit delay block (initialized to `0`).
    *   The output of this block is `DLV_DROF` from *two* sample times ago (`DLV_DROF_delayed_2`).
    *   A third `WRITE BIT` block (with `bit_sel = 2`) takes `y_1` as its `num_dec` input.
    *   It takes `DLV_DROF_delayed_2` as its `bit` input.
    *   It writes `DLV_DROF_delayed_2` into bit position 2 of `y_1`.

*   A third `WRITE BIT` block (with `bit_sel = 2`) takes `y_1` as its `num_dec` input.
    *   It takes `DLV_DROF_delayed_2` as its `bit` input.
    *   It writes `DLV_DROF_delayed_2` into bit position 2 of `y_1`. The output `y` (`y_2`) now includes `DLV_DROF` from 2 samples ago in bit 2.

5.  **`DLV_DROF` from 3 Samples Ago (Bit 3):**
    *   `DLV_DROF_delayed_2` feeds into a third `1/z` unit delay block (initialized to `0`).
    *   The output of this block is `DLV_DROF` from *three* sample times ago (`DLV_DROF_delayed_3`).
    *   A fourth `WRITE BIT` block (with `bit_sel = 3`) takes `y_2` as its `num_dec` input.
    *   It takes `DLV_DROF_delayed_3` as its `bit` input.
    *   It writes `DLV_DROF_delayed_3` into bit position 3 of `y_2`. The output `y` (`y_3`) now includes `DLV_DROF` from 3 samples ago in bit 3.

6.  **`DLV_DROF` from 4 Samples Ago (Bit 4):**
    *   `DLV_DROF_delayed_3` feeds into a fourth `1/z` unit delay block (initialized to `0`).
    *   The output of this block is `DLV_DROF` from *four* sample times ago (`DLV_DROF_delayed_4`).
    *   A fifth `WRITE BIT` block (with `bit_sel = 4`) takes `y_3` as its `num_dec` input.
    *   It takes `DLV_DROF_delayed_4` as its `bit` input.
    *   It writes `DLV_DROF_delayed_4` into bit position 4 of `y_3`. The output `y` (`y_4`) now includes `DLV_DROF` from 4 samples ago in bit 4.

7.  **Final Output:**
    *   The final output `y_4` is routed to the output port labeled `STATE_DROF`. This integer value encapsulates the last five states of the `DLV_DROF` signal. For example, if `DLV_DROF` was `[1, 0, 1, 1, 0]` (current to 4 samples ago), `STATE_DROF` would be `01101` in binary, which is `13` in decimal.

## Function
The system depicted is a component of an "Engine speed setpoint calculation (ENSC)" module, crucial for automotive powertrain control. It serves two primary functions:
1.  **Initialization during Engine Transitions**: To ensure a controlled and stable state, it initializes and resets several key engine speed setpoint variables (e.g., corrected drive speed, ramp values) when the engine transitions from a running state to a stopped state. This prevents stale or erroneous values from affecting subsequent operations.
2.  **Operational Level Powertrain Control**: It dynamically selects between a hybrid powertrain (PT) plant and a combustion-based PT plant, performs the relevant operational calculations, and consolidates their respective system outputs into a single, unified signal bus. This allows the system to adapt its control strategy based on the vehicle's powertrain configuration.

## Inputs
The system receives various inputs to control its initialization and operational logic:

*   **Triggers/Control Signals (from top diagram):**
    *   `f()`: A functional call or trigger signal, likely to initiate the initialization sequence.
    *   `fc`: Another functional call or trigger signal, similar to `f()`, for initialization.
*   **Powertrain Selection Parameters (from bottom diagram):**
    *   `<NO_PT_TYP>`: Number of available powertrain types.
    *   `<LV_VAR_HYB>`: A level variable indicating the status or activity level of the hybrid system.
    *   `<NC_PT_TYP_CMB_ENG>`: Number of combustion engine powertrain types.
    *   `<NC_PT_TYP_HYB>`: Number of hybrid powertrain types.
*   **Plant-Specific Inputs (from bottom diagram):**
    *   `<input>` (to OPM_SYS_HYB): General input signal(s) required for the "Hybrid PT plant" calculation.
    *   `<input>` (to OPM_SYS_CMB_ENG): General input signal(s) required for the "Combustion based PT plant" calculation.
    *   `<feedback>`: A specific feedback signal provided to the "Combustion based PT plant" calculation.

## Outputs
The system produces several outputs, primarily involving updates to internal data stores and a consolidated operational bus:

*   **Initialized Setpoint Variables (Data Store Writes from top diagram):**
    *   `N_SP_IS_COR_DRIV`: The corrected drive speed setpoint, initialized to zero.
    *   `N_SP_IS_RAMP`: The speed ramp value, initialized to zero.

*   `N_SP_IS_RAMP`: The speed ramp value, initialized to zero.

## Logic Flow

The system operates in two distinct phases or levels, as described by the section headings:

**Part 1: 30.4.1.4 Initialization during Engine run to Engine stop**
1.  **Trigger Activation**: The initialization process is activated by incoming trigger signals `f()` and `fc`. These signals typically signify an event such as an engine shutdown request or a system reset.
2.  **Setpoint Reset**: Upon activation, the system sets five specific engine speed setpoint variables to a constant value of '0'. These variables, which are likely stored in Data Store Memory blocks, include: `N_SP_IS_COR_DRIV`, `N_SP_IS_RAMP`, `N_SP_IS_RAMP_TAR`, `LV_N_SP_IS_RAMP`, and `LV_N_SP_IS_RAMP_ACT`.
3.  **Purpose**: This logic ensures that crucial speed control parameters are cleared and brought to a default (zero) state when the engine stops or transitions, preventing carry-over values from previous operations from affecting subsequent engine start-ups or control cycles.

**Part 2: 30.4.2 Operation level**
1.  **Powertrain Selection**: The "HYBRID & COMBUSTION VEHICLE SELECTION COMPILER_HYB" block (X.2.1) acts as a control logic unit. It takes various inputs such as `<NO_PT_TYP>`, `<LV_VAR_HYB>`, `<NC_PT_TYP_CMB_ENG>`, and `<NC_PT_TYP_HYB>`. Based on these inputs, it determines whether the vehicle operates with a hybrid or a purely combustion-based powertrain. It then outputs control signals, `<fct_comb>` and `<fct_hyb>`, which likely act as enable flags or parameters for the respective plant calculation blocks.
2.  **Hybrid Plant Calculation**: The "Calculation for Hybrid PT plant OPM_SYS_HYB" block (X.2.2) receives its specific `<input>` signals. When enabled or parameterized by the `<fct_hyb>` signal, it performs detailed calculations relevant to the operational characteristics and control of a hybrid powertrain system. Its result is the `opm_sys_hyb` signal.
3.  **Combustion Plant Calculation**: Similarly, the "Calculation for Combustion based PT plant OPM_SYS_CMB_ENG" block (X.2.3) receives its specific `<input>` signals and a `<feedback>` signal. When enabled or parameterized by the `<fct_comb>` signal, it performs detailed calculations pertaining to the operational characteristics and control of a combustion engine powertrain. Its result is the `opm_sys_cmb_eng` signal.
4.  **Output Merging**: The individual operational outputs from both plant calculations, `opm_sys_hyb` and `opm_sys_cmb_eng`, are then fed into a `BusMerge` block (V.6.6).
5.  **Unified Output**: The `BusMerge` block combines these distinct signals into a single, structured output called `<signalbus>`. This unified bus provides a consolidated view or set of control parameters for the currently active powertrain plant, simplifying its interface with higher-level control modules.

*   **NC_PT_TYP_CMB_ENG**: A specific bit or mask used in conjunction with `NC_PT_TYP` to identify if combustion engine features are enabled within the overall powertrain type.

*   **`#fct_hyb`**: Represents the compilation or execution of functionalities specific to hybrid vehicles.
*   **`#fct_comb`**: Represents the compilation or execution of functionalities specific to non-hybrid (combustion engine) vehicles.

Essentially, the diagram selects which set of control logic (hybrid or combustion-only) is applied.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Initial Hybrid Variant Check:** The process begins with an 'If' block (labeled `cond_if`) that evaluates the state of `LV_VAR_HYB`.
    *   **If `LV_VAR_HYB` is true (or high):** The logic proceeds along the "if" path (top branch), indicating a potential hybrid vehicle configuration.
    *   **If `LV_VAR_HYB` is false (or low):** The logic proceeds along the "else" path (bottom branch), indicating a potential non-hybrid (combustion engine only) vehicle configuration.

3.  **Non-Hybrid System Activation (Bottom Path):**
    *   Along the "else" path, another 'AND' block performs a bitwise AND operation between `NC_PT_TYP` and `NC_PT_TYP_CMB_ENG`. This checks if the specific bit(s) representing "combustion engine" are set within the general `NC_PT_TYP` configuration.
    *   If the result of this bitwise AND operation is true (meaning combustion engine features are configured and `LV_VAR_HYB` is false), the `#fct_comb` block is activated. This block signifies the compilation or activation of functions specifically designed for non-hybrid (combustion engine) systems.

In summary, the diagram acts as a conditional gate, first using `LV_VAR_HYB` to decide between hybrid and non-hybrid branches, and then using bitwise comparisons with `NC_PT_TYP` to confirm the specific powertrain type configuration before activating the corresponding functional block (`#fct_hyb` or `#fct_comb`). ## Logic Flow

The logic flow for both automatic and manual transmissions ultimately combines several conditions using an OR gate to produce the final `LV_N_SP_IS_RAMP_ENA` signal. This means that if *any* of the defined conditions for enabling ramping are met, the ramping functionality will be activated.

### Logic Flow for Automatic Transmissions (N_SP_IS_RAMP_AT_ENA)

This diagram evaluates three main groups of conditions: brake status, ignition/gear position, and cruise control/DCT status.

1.  **Brake Condition Branch:**
    *   `LV_BLS` (Brake Light Switch) and `LV_BTS` (Brake Test Switch) are combined with an OR gate. If either is TRUE, the output is TRUE.
    *   `PRS_BRAKE_CAN` (Brake pressure) is compared with `C_MIN_PRS_BRAKE_N_SP_IS_RAMP` using a `>=` (greater than or equal to) operator. The output `LC_N_SP_IS_RAMP_BRAKE` is TRUE if the brake pressure meets or exceeds the threshold.
    *   The OR result of `LV_BLS`/`LV_BTS` and `LC_N_SP_IS_RAMP_BRAKE` are combined with an AND gate. This means that for this branch to be TRUE, either `LV_BLS` or `LV_BTS` must be TRUE *AND* the brake pressure must be sufficient. This composite signal forms the first input to the final OR gate. (Logic: (`LV_BLS` OR `LV_BTS`) AND (`PRS_BRAKE_CAN` >= `C_MIN_PRS_BRAKE_N_SP_IS_RAMP`)).

2.  **Ignition and Gear Position Branch:**
    *   `LV_IGS_ACT` (Ignition Active) is passed through a NOT gate. So, this condition is TRUE if the ignition is *not* active (e.g., engine off).
    *   The `P` (Park) signal is compared for equality with the constant `8`.
    *   The `N` (Neutral) signal is compared for equality with the constant `6`.
    *   The `SEL_PSN3` signal is compared for equality with the constant `3`.
    *   The results of `P==8`, `N==6`, and `SEL_PSN3==3` are combined with an OR gate. This sub-condition is TRUE if the selector is in Park, Neutral, or Position 3.
    *   The NOT `LV_IGS_ACT` and the OR result of the gear positions (`LC_N_SP_IS_RAMP_DRIVE`) are combined with an AND gate. This forms the second input to the final OR gate.

*   The results of `P==8`, `N==6`, and `SEL_PSN3==3` are combined with an OR gate. This sub-condition is TRUE if the selector is in Park, Neutral, or Position 3.
    *   The NOT `LV_IGS_ACT` and the OR result of the gear positions (`LC_N_SP_IS_RAMP_DRIVE`) are combined with an AND gate. This forms the second input to the final OR gate. (Logic: (NOT `LV_IGS_ACT`) AND (`P==8` OR `N==6` OR `SEL_PSN3==3`)).

3.  **Cruise Control and DCT Branch:**
    *   `STATE_CC` (Cruise Control State) is compared for equality with the constant `0` (often signifying 'inactive' or 'off').
    *   The result of `STATE_CC == 0` is ANDed with `LV_DCT` (Dual Clutch Transmission condition). This result, `LC_N_SP_IS_RAMP_DCT`, forms the third input to the final OR gate. (Logic: (`STATE_CC==0`) AND `LV_DCT`).

4.  **Final Output:** The outputs of the three branches are combined using a final OR gate. `LV_N_SP_IS_RAMP_ENA` is TRUE if any of the three main conditions (Brake related, Ignition/Gear Position related, or Cruise Control/DCT related) evaluate to TRUE.

### Logic Flow for Manual Transmissions (N_SP_IS_RAMP_MT_ENA)

This diagram evaluates conditions related to vehicle/engine speed ratio, clutch status, and a direct manual enable.

1.  **Vehicle/Engine Speed Ratio and Clutch Branch:**
    *   `VS` (Vehicle Speed) is divided by `N` (Engine Speed). This ratio often indicates a "pseudo" gear ratio or slip.
    *   The result of `VS / N` is compared with `C_N_SP_IS_VS_N_THD` (a threshold constant) using a `<=` (less than or equal to) operator. The output `LC_N_SP_IS_RAMP_VS_N` is TRUE if the ratio is below or at the threshold.
    *   `LC_N_SP_IS_RAMP_VS_N` is ANDed with `LV_N_SP_IS_CLU_OPEN` (Clutch Open status). This forms the first input to the final OR gate. (Logic: (`VS/N <= C_N_SP_IS_VS_N_THD`) AND `LV_N_SP_IS_CLU_OPEN`). This condition likely enables ramping when the vehicle is slowing down, possibly in neutral or with the clutch pressed, and the engine speed needs to be controlled (e.g., to prevent stalling or for smooth idle return).

2.  **Manual Ramping Branch:**
    *   `LC_N_SP_IS_RAMP_MAN` (Manual Ramping Enable) is directly fed as the second input to the final OR gate. This acts as a direct override or an alternative condition to enable ramping.

3.  **Final Output:** The outputs of the two branches are combined using a final OR gate. `LV_N_SP_IS_RAMP_ENA` is TRUE if either the vehicle speed/engine speed ratio with clutch open condition is met OR the `LC_N_SP_IS_RAMP_MAN` signal is TRUE.

This Simulink diagram, titled "Engine mechanical conditions (CLC_N_SP_IS_ENG)" within the context of "ENSC: Engine speed setpoint calculation", is designed to evaluate a set of critical engine "hot detection" conditions. Its primary function is to determine a boolean or state variable, `N_SP_IS_ENG`, which indicates whether the engine speed setpoint is currently under the influence of, or "engaged" due to, detected hot mechanical or thermal conditions.

The logic works by checking if various temperature-related values (`_TOL_SRV_INTL_S`, `_TCO_`, `_TIA_`) exceed predefined thresholds, coupled with an overall hot detection enable signal (`LC_N_SP_IS_HOT_DET_ENA`). If all these hot conditions are met and enabled, the output `N_SP_IS_ENG` is allowed to hold its current value (implying another part of the system would set its initial non-zero state). If any of these hot conditions are *not* met or the system is disabled, `N_SP_IS_ENG` is gradually driven to zero through a rate limiter, ensuring a smooth and controlled disengagement from the "hot condition" state.

This means the VECU request is active if *either* Engine Management Request 1 *or* Additive CAN Request 1 (under their respective enabling conditions) is true.
*   **VECU Request Invalid Generation:** `LV_N_SP_IS_VECU_REQ` is passed through an **inverter** (indicated by the small circle on the output of the OR gate's connection to `LV_N_SP_IS_VECU_RI`). *   **Engine Management 2 Condition:** The input `LV_N_SP_IS_EGY_MNG_2` is ANDed with its enable signal `LC_N_SP_IS_EGY_MNG_2_ENA` and the general Engine Management CAN variable `LV_EGY_MNG_CAN_VAR`. This forms `Cond_EGY_MNG_2_Active`.

*   **Step 2 Activation:** `Cond_EGY_MNG_2_Active` and `Cond_ADD_CAN_2_Active` are fed into an **OR** gate. The output of this OR gate is `LV_N_SP_IS_STEP_2`. This means Step 2 is active if *either* Engine Management Request 2 *or* Additive CAN Request 2 (under their respective enabling conditions) is true.

**3. Determination of `LV_N_SP_IS_STEP_3`:**

*   **Step 3 Activation:** The output of this AND gate is `LV_N_SP_IS_STEP_3`. This means Step 3 is active if `LV_N_SP_IS_EGY_MNG_1` *and* `LV_N_SP_IS_EGY_MNG_3` *and* its enable signal `LC_N_SP_IS_EGY_MNG_3_ENA` are all true.

## Logic Flow

The diagram's logic can be broadly divided into three main sections: AC Request Signaling, AC Engine Speed Setpoint Calculation, and Heating Request & Engine Speed Setpoint Calculation.

**1. AC Request Signaling (Top Left & Top Right):**
*   **AC Increase Request (`LV_N_SP_IS_AC_INC`):** This output is determined by ORing multiple sources:
    *   An AND condition of `LV_CAN_ACC_ON_PRE_WARN` and `LC_N_SP_IS_ACC_PRE_WARN` (pre-warnings).
    *   This result is then OR'd with the `LC_N_SP_IS_AC_SW` (local AC switch).
    *   The outcome is further OR'd with `LV_AC_SW_CAN_ON` (CAN AC switch) to produce `LV_N_SP_IS_AC_INC`. This means if any of these conditions are true, an AC-related engine speed increase is flagged.
*   **Overall AC Request (`LV_N_SP_IS_AC_REQ`):** This output is true if (`LV_N_SP_IS_AC_INC` OR `LV_AC_SW_CAN_ON`) is true AND `LC_N_SP_IS_AC_REQ_ENA` (AC request enable) is true. This acts as a master enable for the AC system.

**2. AC Engine Speed Setpoint Calculation (`N_SP_IS_AC`) (Middle Section):**
This section calculates the actual engine speed adjustment needed for AC. It has two main parallel paths that feed into a maximum selector:

*   **Basic AC Switch Request Path (Upper Middle):**
    *   `C_N_SP_IS_ACC_SW_DRI` (driver switch) and `C_N_SP_IS_ACC_SW` (auto switch) are processed through "Switch" blocks (threshold 0.5) and internal `LV_DRI`/`LV_AT` logic.
    *   The derived signals, along with `LC_N_SP_IS_ACCIN_ON` and `LV_AC_SW_CAN_ON`, are combined via AND gates (`LV_ACCIN_ON_CAN`).
    *   The result of this AND gate controls a "Switch ON (AUDI) AC Compressor OFF" block. If true, it outputs a calculated value (representing the engine speed increase for basic AC); otherwise, it outputs 0.

*   **Maximum AC Power Request Path (Lower Middle):**
    *   `C_N_SP_IS_AC_MAX_PWR_DRI` (driver max power) and `C_N_SP_IS_AC_MAX_PWR` (auto max power) are processed similarly through "Switch" blocks and internal `LV_DRI`/`LV_AT` logic.
    *   The derived signals, along with `C_TAM_N_SP_IS_ACIN`, are combined via AND gates (`LV_ACIN_CAN`).
    *   The result of this AND gate controls an "AC ECU request for increasing N_IS" block. If true, it outputs a calculated value (for max AC power); otherwise, it outputs 0.

*   **Final AC Engine Speed Calculation:**
    *   The outputs from both the "Basic AC Switch" and "Maximum AC Power" selector blocks are fed into a `max` block. This selects the higher engine speed requirement of the two.

*   The result of this AND gate controls an "AC ECU request for increasing N_IS" block. If true, it outputs a calculated value (for max AC power); otherwise, it outputs 0.

*   **Final AC Engine Speed Calculation:**
    *   The outputs from both the "Basic AC Switch" and "Maximum AC Power" selector blocks are fed into a `max` block. This selects the higher engine speed requirement of the two.
    *   This maximal value, along with `LV_N_SP_IS_AC_INC` and various vehicle operating parameters (`<TCO>`, `<LV_DRI>`, `<LV_AT>`, `<LV_CVT>`, `<TQI>`), are fed into the complex block "N_SP_IS_AC Request while Compressor is Active". This block performs detailed calculations based on these inputs to determine the final `N_SP_IS_AC` (engine speed setpoint for AC).

**3. Heating Request & Engine Speed Setpoint Calculation (Bottom Section):**
*   **Heating Request Status:**
    *   `LV_REQ_HEAT_CAN` (CAN heat request) is AND'd with the result of a comparison: `STATE_HEAT_REQ_AC_CAN` must be greater than `C_THD_HEAT_REQ_AC_CAN` (heating request threshold). This determines if a heating request is active from the CAN.
*   **Overall Heating Request (`LV_N_SP_IS_HEAT_REQ`):** This output is true if the derived CAN heating request is active AND `LC_N_SP_IS_HEAT_REQ_ENA` (heating request enable) is true.
*   **Heating Engine Speed Calculation (`N_SP_IS_HEAT`):**
    *   The derived CAN heating request (from the comparison and `LV_REQ_HEAT_CAN`), along with `LV_N_SP_IS_HEAT_INC` (an input signaling an external heating increase request), and various vehicle operating parameters (`<TCO>`, `<LV_DRI>`, `<IDX_TRANS_TYP>`, `<NC_NR_IP_N_SP_IS_HEAT>`), are fed into the "Climate_request_Heating_on" block (which appears to be part of the larger "N_SP_IS_AC Request while Compressor is Active" system). This block calculates the final `N_SP_IS_HEAT` (engine speed setpoint for heating).

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate and provide an engine idle speed setpoint (`N_SP_IS_AC`) specifically required when the air conditioning (AC) compressor is active. It achieves this by referencing several 2D look-up tables, which map engine coolant temperature (`TCO`) and engine oil temperature (`TOIL`) to idle speed requests. The selection of the appropriate look-up table and subsequent processing (rate limiting, maximum selection) depends on the active transmission type (e.g., Manual, Automatic, CVT, DCT) and specific drive conditions.

## Inputs

*   **<TCO>**: Engine Coolant Temperature (signal, typically degrees Celsius). Used as the x-axis input for all 2D look-up tables.
*   **<TOIL>**: Engine Oil Temperature (signal, typically degrees Celsius). Used as the y-axis input for all 2D look-up tables.
*   **<LV_DRI>**: Logical/Boolean flag indicating "Drive" mode for relevant transmissions (e.g., used to select between a general transmission map and a drive-specific map).
*   **<LV_DCT>**: Logical/Boolean flag indicating if a Dual Clutch Transmission (DCT) is active or selected.
*   **<LV_AT>**: Logical/Boolean flag indicating if an Automatic Transmission (AT) is active or selected.
*   **<LV_N_SP_IS_AC_INC>**: Logical/Boolean flag indicating if an overall AC idle speed increase is requested or enabled.
*   **IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_DRI (V.7.3)**: 2D Look-up table data (parameter) for AC idle speed in "Drive" mode.
*   **IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_CVT (V.7.3)**: 2D Look-up table data (parameter) for AC idle speed with a Continuously Variable Transmission (CVT).
*   **IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_DRI_DCT (V.7.3)**: 2D Look-up table data (parameter) for AC idle speed in "Drive" mode with a DCT.

*   **IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_CVT (V.7.3)**: 2D Look-up table data (parameter) for AC idle speed with a Continuously Variable Transmission (CVT).
*   **IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_DRI_DCT (V.7.3)**: 2D Look-up table data (parameter) for AC idle speed in "Drive" mode with a DCT.
*   **IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_DCT (V.7.3)**: 2D Look-up table data (parameter) for AC idle speed with a DCT (general).
*   **IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_DRI_AT (V.7.3)**: 2D Look-up table data (parameter) for AC idle speed in "Drive" mode with an AT.
*   **IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_AT (V.7.3)**: 2D Look-up table data (parameter) for AC idle speed with an AT (general).
*   **IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_MT (V.7.3)**: 2D Look-up table data (parameter) for AC idle speed with a Manual Transmission (MT).

## Outputs

*   **N_SP_IS_AC**: The final engine idle speed setpoint (in RPM, likely) requested due to the active AC compressor.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow calculates the AC-induced idle speed setpoint through a series of steps involving look-up table evaluations, conditional selections, maximum value determination, and rate limiting:

1.  **Individual Look-up Table Evaluation:**
    *   Seven 2D look-up tables are evaluated in parallel. Each table (`IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_DRI`, `IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_CVT`, etc.) takes `TCO` and `TOIL` as inputs.
    *   These tables output an idle speed request value corresponding to the current engine temperatures for a specific transmission type and drive condition.

2.  **Transmission-Specific Request Selection and Rate Limiting (Parallel Branches):**
    *   **DRI/CVT Branch:** A Switch block (controlled by `<LV_DRI>`) selects between the `IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_DRI` output (if `<LV_DRI>` is true/1) and the `IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_CVT` output (if `<LV_DRI>` is false/0). The selected value then passes through a Rate Limiter block (with a maximum rate of change of 0.5 units/second, likely RPM/s).
    *   **DCT Branch:** A Switch block (controlled by `<LV_DCT>`) selects between the `IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_DRI_DCT` output (if `<LV_DCT>` is true/1) and the `IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_DCT` output (if `<LV_DCT>` is false/0). This selected value then passes through a Rate Limiter (0.5).
    *   **AT Branch:** A Switch block (controlled by `<LV_AT>`) selects between the `IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_DRI_AT` output (if `<LV_AT>` is true/1) and the `IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_AT` output (if `<LV_AT>` is false/0). This selected value then passes through a Rate Limiter (0.5).
    *   **MT Branch:** The output of the `IP_N_SP_IS_ACIN_MT` look-up table passes directly through its own Rate Limiter (0.5), as there's no drive-specific variant shown for MT.

3.  **Cascaded Maximum Selection:**
    *   The rate-limited outputs from the four primary branches (DRI/CVT selected, DCT selected, AT selected, MT) are fed into a series of cascaded Max blocks (represented by the `>` symbol, which signifies finding the maximum of its inputs).
    *   First, a Max block compares the DRI/CVT selected output with the DCT selected output.
    *   The result of this first Max block is then compared with the AT selected output in a second Max block.
    *   Finally, the result of the second Max block is compared with the MT selected output in a third Max block.
    *   This ensures that the highest idle speed request among all active and selected transmission-specific conditions is propagated.

4.  **Final Enablement and Smoothing:**
    *   The output of the cascaded Max blocks (representing the highest idle speed request) is fed into a final Switch block.
    *   This switch is controlled by the `<LV_N_SP_IS_AC_INC>` signal.

*   This ensures that the highest idle speed request among all active and selected transmission-specific conditions is propagated.

4.  **Final Enablement and Smoothing:**
    *   The output of the cascaded Max blocks (representing the highest idle speed request) is fed into a final Switch block.
    *   This switch is controlled by the `<LV_N_SP_IS_AC_INC>` signal.
    *   If `<LV_N_SP_IS_AC_INC>` is true (1), the switch outputs the maximum idle speed request determined in the previous step.
    *   If `<LV_N_SP_IS_AC_INC>` is false (0), the switch outputs `0`, effectively disabling the AC-induced idle speed increase.
    *   The final output of this switch then passes through one last Rate Limiter (0.5) to ensure a smooth transition to the final `N_SP_IS_AC` setpoint.

    *   Otherwise (if `T_AST < C_T_DLY_N_SP`), a constant value of `0` is passed through, effectively deactivating the setpoint or setting it to a minimum.
    *   The output of this final switch block is the `N_SP_IS_COR`, representing the coordinated and activated engine speed setpoint.

## Function
This Simulink diagram, spanning Figures 304.38 and 304.39, describes the comprehensive logic for **Engine Speed Setpoint Calculation and Final Coordination, particularly for Idle Speed (N_SP_IS)**. It processes various raw speed requests (OEM, customer, transmission, electrical balance, EOL) and applies filtering, rate limiting, and absolute physical limits to derive a robust and safe engine speed setpoint.

## Inputs
*   `N_SP_IS_DROF_OEMS`: Nominal OEM drive-off (drof) speed setpoint.
*   `N_SP_IS_DROF_AT_CUS`: Customer-specific drive-off (drof) speed setpoint.
*   `V_LV_IGK`: Ignition key status or voltage, used for engine start/enable logic.
*   `N_SP_IS_COR_MAX`: Corridor maximum speed setpoint, a dynamic upper bound.
*   `C_N_SP_IS_MAX_CLC`: Calculated absolute maximum speed limit.
*   `C_N_SP_IS_MAX`: Static absolute maximum speed limit.
*   `N_SP_IS_SPT_PLS`: Setpoint "plus" or temporary speed increase request.
*   `C_N_SP_IS_DROF_LGRD_UP`: Configurable rate limit for increasing drof speed.
*   `C_N_SP_IS_DROF_LGRD_DOWN`: Configurable rate limit for decreasing drof speed.
*   `N_SP_IS_REQ_ER_BAL_HOM`: Requested electrical balance home idle speed setpoint.
*   `LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_IS_ENA_EXT`: External enable for the electrical balance home range (boolean or 0/1 signal).
*   `N_SP_IS_EOL`: End-Of-Line (test/calibration mode) idle speed setpoint.
*   `CTR_EOL`: Counter value for End-Of-Line mode, used to enable the EOL setpoint.
*   `N_SP_IS_TRANS`: Transmission-related idle speed setpoint.
*   `N_SP_IS_LIM`: Limited engine speed setpoint (an output from Fig 304.38, also used as an input to Fig 304.39).
*   `N_SP_IS_DROF`: Drof speed setpoint (an intermediate output from Fig 304.38, used as an input to Fig 304.39).
*   `LC_N_SP_IS_DROF_MIN_CLU_ENA`: Logic for minimum drof speed when clutch is enabled.
*   `N_SP_IS_LIH`: Limit High setpoint.

## Outputs
*   `N_SP_IS`: The final, coordinated, and limited engine idle speed setpoint.
*   `N_SP_IS_RVM`: The reverse speed setpoint, selected from available limits.
*   `N_SP_IS_DROF_OEM_FIL`: The rate-limited and filtered OEM/customer-selected drof speed setpoint.
*   `N_SP_IS_INTER_MAX`: An intermediate maximum speed setpoint.

## Logic Flow

The overall logic can be broken down into two main parts corresponding to the figures: calculating a rate-limited drof setpoint and various limits (Figure 304.38), and then coordinating these and other specific setpoints into a final idle speed (Figure 304.39).

### Part 1: Initial Setpoint and Limit Calculation (Figure 304.38)

1.  **Base Drof Setpoint Selection:** The system first determines the base drof setpoint (`N_SP_IS_DROF_OEM`) by taking the maximum of the OEM nominal drof speed (`N_SP_IS_DROF_OEMS`) and a customer-specific drof speed (`N_SP_IS_DROF_AT_CUS`).
2.  **Gradient Limiter Enable Logic:**
    *   An `EdgeRising` block detects a positive transition on the ignition key signal (`V_LV_IGK`).
    *   This rising edge signal, along with a check if the base drof setpoint (`N_SP_IS_DROF_OEM`) is greater than 0, are combined using an `OR` gate. This result sets the `SRFlipFlop`.
    *   The `SRFlipFlop` is reset if `N_SP_IS_COR_MAX` (Corridor Maximum Speed) becomes inactive (e.g., 0), as indicated by a `NOT` block before the `R` input.
    *   The `Q` output of this `SRFlipFlop` enables (`E`) the `GradientLimiter` block, ensuring the rate limiter is active only under appropriate conditions (e.g., after ignition or an initial setpoint request).
3.

*   The `Q` output of this `SRFlipFlop` enables (`E`) the `GradientLimiter` block, ensuring the rate limiter is active only under appropriate conditions (e.g., after ignition or an initial setpoint request).
3.  **Drof Setpoint Rate Limiting:**
    *   The `GradientLimiter` block (`GRD Generic: Multi & Singlerat`) receives the base drof setpoint (`N_SP_IS_DROF_OEM`) as its input (`u`).
    *   Its initial value (`IV`) is set by `N_SP_IS_COR_MAX`.
    *   It applies configurable rate limits: `C_N_SP_IS_DROF_LGRD_UP` for increases and `C_N_SP_IS_DROF_LGRD_DOWN` for decreases.
    *   The output `y` of the `GradientLimiter` is the rate-limited and filtered drof setpoint (`N_SP_IS_DROF_OEM_FIL`).
4.  **Intermediate Maximum Speed Calculation:**
    *   `N_SP_IS_INTER_MAX` is calculated as the maximum of `N_SP_IS_COR_MAX` and `N_SP_IS_SPT_PLS`.
5.  **Limited Speed Setpoint (`N_SP_IS_LIM`) Calculation:**
    *   An intermediate value is obtained by taking the maximum of `N_SP_IS_COR_MAX` and `N_SP_IS_SPT_PLS`.
    *   This value is then capped by the absolute limits `C_N_SP_IS_MAX_CLC` and `C_N_SP_IS_MAX` using a `min` block.
    *   The result, `N_SP_IS_LIM`, undergoes a `Check ~= 0` validation.

### Part 2: Final Idle Speed Coordination (Figure 304.39)

1.  **Electrical Balance Home Setpoint Processing:**
    *   The `N_SP_IS_REQ_ER_BAL_HOM` (requested electrical balance home setpoint) is conditionally passed or limited by `LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_IS_ENA_EXT` using a `min` block. If `LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_IS_ENA_EXT` is effectively 0 (e.g., "disabled"), the output (`LV_N_SP_IS_LIH`) becomes 0, otherwise, it allows `N_SP_IS_REQ_ER_BAL_HOM` to pass through (or limits it if `LV_ER_BAL_HOM_RNG_IS_ENA_EXT` is a numerical limit).
2.  **End-Of-Line (EOL) Setpoint Integration:**
    *   The `N_SP_IS_EOL` setpoint is enabled only if `CTR_EOL` is greater than `0`, using an `AND` gate.
    *   The enabled `N_SP_IS_EOL` (or 0 if disabled) is then compared with `LV_N_SP_IS_LIH` (from step 1) using a `max` block, selecting the higher of the two.
3.  **Final Idle Speed (`N_SP_IS`) Derivation:**
    *   The result from step 2 is then limited by `N_SP_IS_LIH` (Limit High setpoint) using a `min` block.

## Outputs

*   **N_DIF_COR**: The corrected engine speed deviation. This output is dynamically selected between `N_DIF` and a deviation calculated using `N_SP_IS_CLC`, based on the `LC_N_SP_IS_CLC_ACT` signal.

The subsystem operates in two main parallel paths to produce its outputs:

**1. Calculation of N_DIF:**
    *   The `N_SP_IS` (desired idle speed set point) and `N` (actual engine speed) signals are fed into a summation block (labeled `V.6.7`).

## Logic Flow
The subsystem operates in two main parallel paths to produce its outputs:

**1. Calculation of N_DIF:**
    *   The `N_SP_IS` (desired idle speed set point) and `N` (actual engine speed) signals are fed into a summation block (labeled `V.6.7`).
    *   Inside this summation block, `N` is subtracted from `N_SP_IS` (`N_SP_IS - N`), yielding the basic engine speed deviation. A positive value indicates the actual speed is below the desired, while a negative value indicates overspeed.
    *   This deviation signal is then passed through a gain block (labeled `V.6.1`), which, in this context, likely acts as an identity gain (1) to simply output the signal as `N_DIF`.

**2. Calculation of N_DIF_COR:**

    *   Similar to the `N_DIF` calculation, `N` is subtracted from `N_SP_IS_CLC` (`N_SP_IS_CLC - N`). This provides a potential alternative deviation value when the corrected set point is active.
    *   The outputs of both summation blocks (`N_SP_IS - N` which is `N_DIF`, and `N_SP_IS_CLC - N`) along with the `LC_N_SP_IS_CLC_ACT` control signal are fed into a selector or switch block (labeled `V.6.4` with "threshold: 0.5").

Based on the accompanying text, when `LC_N_SP_IS_CLC_ACT` is active (e.g., its value exceeds 0.5), the output `N_DIF_COR` will be the deviation calculated using `N_SP_IS_CLC` (`N_SP_IS_CLC - N`). Otherwise, `N_DIF_COR` will typically default to the `N_DIF` value (`N_SP_IS - N`). This mechanism allows for a dynamic adjustment of the feedback deviation depending on the operational needs, especially during engine speed transients.
    *   The selected deviation is then outputted as `N_DIF_COR`, the second output of the subsystem.
